title: What is your favorite American (US) march? - Quora

response.answer_text: What is your favorite American (US) march? Anchors Aweigh. However, not just any Anchors Aweigh will do. There’s a lot of Anchors Aweigh abominations out there. They are not subtle, have little sophistication, and throw away most of the march. They start with the trio and leave off the first two strains. The following performance is by a very good Japanese high school ensemble, and they perform Charles A. Zimmerman’s Anchors Aweigh as it was intended, full bore, from the beginning, with all the subtlety and bombasticness the piece contains and deserves. This is not a watered-down for public consumption Anchors Aweigh. It goes places and knocks the barnacles off.  There’s a good US Navy Band performance out there as well, but I couldn’t find it. Most of the Anchors Aweigh recordings are arrangements and not the original. I actually have dozens of favorite marches from Spanish to British to German to American and many others, but I’ll just leave you with John Williams’ Midway March, another American nautical masterpiece. This march has a nice lilt to it, and is very cinematic, of course.

If I had to name one march that is both a unique United States-originating composition and is a personal favorite, then I’d have to nominate John P. Sousa’s “Stars and Stripes Forever”. “Hurrah for the flag of the free! May it wave as our standard forever! The gem of the land and the sea, the banner of the right! Let tyrants remember the day when our fathers with mighty endeavor, Proclaim as they marched to the fray That by their might and by their right It waves forever!”  Performance by the U.S. Army Field Band and Soldiers’ Chorus (2013)
